topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Carole Robin, her Stanford “Touchy Feely” course, her book Connect, and what the episode will cover (mental models, disclosure, three realities, feedback, vulnerability, relationships).

topics.title: Why robust relationships matter; relationship continuum
topics.summary: Carole defines relationships on a continuum from “contact/no connection” to “exceptional,” arguing most people need at least some high-quality relationships for a meaningful life and healthier organizations/society.

topics.title: Benefits of stronger relationships in life and work
topics.summary: Carole shares outcomes she’s seen from students: improved leadership and business success, better co-founder dynamics, reconciled family relationships, and even marriages saved.

topics.title: What “Touchy Feely” teaches leaders
topics.summary: Carole explains the course’s purpose: building interpersonal competence so people trust you and want to follow you, emphasizing referent power and the question “Why should somebody follow you?”

topics.title: Experiential learning: T-groups and disclosure practice
topics.summary: Carole describes T-groups (training, not therapy), including paired exercises like “allow the other person to get to know you,” debriefing choices made, and using confidentiality to enable real learning.

topics.title: Leaders in Tech programs and how to join
topics.summary: Carole outlines Leaders in Tech: a 10-month Fellows program for founders and a 4-day retreat for tech managers, plus guidance on using the book effectively and where to apply.

topics.title: Progressive disclosure and the 15% rule
topics.summary: Carole explains how relationships deepen through reciprocal vulnerability and introduces the “15% rule” (learning zone vs. danger zone): disclose slightly beyond your comfort zone to grow safely.

topics.title: Appropriate vulnerability in leadership
topics.summary: They discuss context-dependent disclosure—avoiding oversharing while still being real—and how leaders can admit uncertainty in a way that builds credibility and followership.

topics.title: Vulnerability story: becoming a real leader
topics.summary: Carole recounts her early career lesson to “leave feelings in the parking lot,” then a pivotal moment when showing emotion transformed her relationship with her team and solidified her leadership.

topics.title: Feelings vocabulary; anger as secondary emotion
topics.summary: Carole argues feelings give meaning to facts and leaders must use emotions appropriately; she explains anger as a distancing, secondary emotion often masking fear or hurt, with examples of better leadership outcomes.

topics.title: Mental models that limit connection and feedback
topics.summary: They explore how early-formed beliefs (e.g., vulnerability equals weakness; feedback ruins relationships) can become outdated, and why updating mental models is essential for mature leadership and relationships.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Ad read for the a16z Podcast, highlighting interviews with founders, technologists, and leaders shaping the future.

topics.title: Two antennae and the three realities framework
topics.summary: Carole introduces tracking internal vs. external signals (“two antennae”) and explains the “three realities” (intent, behavior, impact) plus “stay on your side of the net” as the foundation for effective feedback.

topics.title: Feedback formula to reduce defensiveness
topics.summary: Using a story with her husband, Carole shows how attributing motives triggers defensiveness; she teaches a behavior→feeling→purpose structure (with real feeling words) to move into collaborative problem-solving.
